Author: soupinate44

Comment: What's wild is these aren't even what reciprocal tariffs are.   Someone calculated them and found the "Tariffs Charged to the US" column is simply the gross import/export deficit, so (gross import - gross export) divided by the gross imports. Then the "reciprocal tariff" is that number divided by 2.   Any country where that value fell below 10% was just set at 10% and any country that would have ballooned the other way due to sanctions were just omitted completely. That's why Russia, Belarus, NK, etc. weren't included.   Canada and Mexico were left off as well due to them being next door neighbors. Their import/exports were nearly identical leading to a near-zero differential. As a result, including them would have set them to 10% which would be a bold-faced lie considering we are currently in a trade war with them that has set much higher tariffs.   That's why countries that don't import much but export a ton like Cambodia have a wild 47% tariff now.
